questions.question_text: An organization expands a Cisco ACI Multi-Pod from two to six pods and must ensure that the control plane scales. What should be configured in the IPN to ensure that BUM traffic is forwarded efficiently across the IPN?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B, according to the document in the link.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/white-paper-c11-739571.html#Option3RoutedfirewallwithL3OutpeeringwiththeCiscoACIfabric

Selected Answer: B
Using separate L3Out peerings ensures that each pod has its own L3Out connection and the firewalls can be set up in an active-standby configuration, providing the necessary external connectivity and redundancy for the Multi-Pod solution.

The question is lacking information, but I agree more on the side of answer A or B A. PBR for routed firewalls
B. separate L3Out peerings for routed firewalls

From my point of view - all answers are possible implementation of firewalls based on attached document. But considering usage for external connectivity - tra transparent firewall and firewall as default gateway are not suitable, because not only external connectivity goes through firewall. You can use L3 out binding for external connectivity (A) but also PBR (B) towards the L3 out ...
it is confusing. I think B C D possible

questions.question_text: An engineer designs a Cisco ACI Multi-Pod solution that requires a pair of active-standby firewalls in different pods for external connectivity. How should the firewalls be implemented?

choices.C: routed firewall for the default gateway
choices.B: separate L3Out peerings for routed firewalls

choices.C: Within a pod, the ingress leaf switch floods the broadcast frame on all fabric ports
choices.D: Ingress replication is used on the spines to forward broadcast frames in the IPN infrastructure
choices.B: Broadcast frames are forwarded inside the pod and across the IPN using the multicast address that is associated to the bridge domain
choices.A: For the specific bridge domain, all spines forward the broadcast frames to IPN routers

questions.question_text: How is broadcast forwarded in Cisco ACI Multi-Pod after ARP flooding is enabled?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Broadcast frames are forwarded inside the pod and across the IPN using the multicast address that is associated to the bridge domain

This is about multipod fabric. Multipod connects Pods via IPN enabled/configured device. We got PIM BIDIR running in IPN (Inter pod network), Protocol Independent Multicast bidirectional. Inside a fabric is standard flooding unless disabled.

Selected Answer: B
agree with apot

questions.question_text:
An engineer configures a Cisco ACI Multi-Pod for disaster recovery. Which action should be taken for the new nodes to be discoverable by the existing Cisco
APICs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I messed with DHCP once and I know in my hearth that it's DHCP RELAY

Selected Answer: C
DHCP relay is required for IPN device in ACI multipod fabric along with PIM-BIDIR.
DHCP relay corresponds to the ability of APIC to identify devices in the fabric through DHCP discovery process.

choices.D: Configure BGP as the underlay protocol in IPN.
choices.A: Enable subinterfaces with dot1q tagging on all links between the IPN routers.
choices.B: Configure IGMPv3 on the interfaces of IPN routers that face the Cisco ACI spine.
choices.C: Enable DHCP relay on all links that are connected to Cisco ACI spines on IPN devices.

questions.question_text: An engineer configures a new Cisco ACI Multi-Pod and must set up the link between the spine and the IPN device. Which three actions should be taken to accomplish this goal? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDF
If this is direct physical connection (configuration can be logical) I would choose OSPF over MP BGP. PIM BIDIR and DHCP relay - yes.
